Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Patient-Specific Instrumentation in Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: Forty patients scheduled for primary TKA were randomised into two groups

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included adults with knee osteoarthritis.

Intervention.evidence: randomised into two groups: PSI and conventional instrumentation

Objective.evidence: investigated whether patient-specific instrumentation (PSI) in total knee arthroplasty (TKA) enhances patient-reported outcomes and gait compared to conventional instrumentation

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was walking speed, assessed using a 3-D gait analysis system

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes

Number_Randomised.evidence: Forty patients scheduled for primary TKA were randomised

Number_Analysed.evidence: All 40 patients completed the study and were analyzed using an intention-to-treat approach

Result_Outcome.evidence: Both groups demonstrated improvements in functional scores, quality of life, and gait parameters from preoperative to 3 months postoperative. However, no significant differences were observed between the PSI and conventional groups in KSS, KOOS, SF-12, or gait parameters.

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.
